case_name: Public limited company (lessee of Minerva, The Globe, Sri Krishna and The Nishat cinema houses) v. Poona City Municipality (body corporate)

facts.text: The appellant is a public limited company registered under the Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a public limited companypany registered under the .

facts.text: The appellant is a lessee of four cinema houses situate within the municipal limits of Poona City known respectively as Minerva, The Globe, Sri Krishna and The Nishat.

anchor.surface_text: It is a lessee of four cinema houses situate within the municipal limits of Poona City known respectively as Minerva, The Globe, Sri Krishna and The Nishat.

facts.text: The appellant exhibits cinematograph films, both foreign and Indian, in the said four houses.

anchor.surface_text: It exhibits cinematograph films, both foreign and Indian, in the said four houses.

facts.text: The respondent, a body corporate, was governed by the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 up to June 8, 1926.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a body companyporate, was governed by the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901  Bom. III of 1901  up to June 8, 1926,

facts.text: The respondent was governed by the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925 up to December 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and from then by the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925  Bom. XVIII of 1925  up to December 29, 1949,

facts.text: The respondent was thereafter governed by the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporation Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and, thereafter, by the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporation Act, 1949  Bom. LIX of 1949 .

facts.text: With effect from October 1, 1920, the respondent levied on the owners and lessees of cinema houses within the limits of the erstwhile province of Bombay a tax of Rs. 2 per day as license fee, with the sanction of the Government of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: With effect from October 1, 1920, the respondent, with the sanction of the Government of Bombay levied on the owners and lessees of cinema houses within the limits of the erstwhile province of Bombay a tax of Rs. 2 per day as license fee.

facts.text: Rules for the levy and collection of the said tax were framed by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Rules for the levy and companylection of the said tax were framed by the respondent.

facts.text: Those rules were amended on or about June 3, 1941, enhancing the tax from Rs. 2 per day to Rs. 1 per show.

anchor.surface_text: Those rules were amended on or about June 3, 1941, enhancing the tax from Rs. 2 per day to Rs. 1 per show.

facts.text: The rules were again revised on or about June 9, 1948, under which the tax was enhanced from Rs. 1 per show to Rs. 5 per show.

anchor.surface_text: The rules were again revised on or about June 9, 1948, under which the tax was enhanced from Rs. 1 per show to Rs. 5 per show.

facts.text: At all material times the tax was being collected at the last mentioned rate.

anchor.surface_text: At all material times the tax was being companylected at the last mentioned rate.

facts.text: Every since the appellant became a lessee of the said cinema houses, the appellant has been making payments of the said tax under protest.

anchor.surface_text: Every since the appellant became a lessee of the said cinema houses, the appellant has been making payments of the said tax under protest.

facts.text: The appellant, on or about March 31, 1950, filed a suit in the Court of the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Poona, being Suit No. 76 of 1950, against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: After giving the necessary statutory numberice to the respondent, the appellant, on or about March 31, 1950, filed a suit in the Court of the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Poona, being Suit No. 76 of 1950,

facts.text: The suit sought declaration that the levy and imposition of the said tax with effect from October 1, 1920, were invalid and illegal, that the enhancement in the rates of the tax with effect first from June 3, 1941, and then June 9, 1948, was invalid and illegal, and that the resolutions passed and rules framed in connection with the levy, imposition, enhancement and collection of the said impugned tax were invalid, illegal and ultra vires, for a permanent injunction, refund and costs.

anchor.surface_text: against the respondent for a declaration that the levy and imposition of the said tax with effect from October 1, 1920, were invalid and illegal that the enhancement in the rates of the tax with effect first from June 3, 1941, and then June 9, 1948, was invalid and illegal and that the resolutions passed and rules framed in companynection with the levy, imposition, enhancement and companylection of the said impugned tax were invalid, illegal and ultra vires, for a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from levying or recovering and or increasing and enhancing the said tax and for refund to the appellant of the amounts of the tax companylection from it and for companyts of the suit and interest.

facts.text: By its judgment dated November 30, 1951, the trial court held that the said tax was validly levied and imposed, but that the increase and enhancement thereof in 1941 and 1948 were illegal and ultra vires and that the suit was not barred under the Acts governing the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated November 30, 1951, the trial companyrt held that the said tax was validly levied and imposed, but that the increase and enhancement thereof in 1941 and 1948 were illegal and ultra vires and that the suit was number barred under the Acts governing the respondent.

facts.text: The trial court decreed the suit in part by issuing an injunction restraining the respondent from levying, recovering or collecting the tax at the enhanced rate and passing a decree against the respondent for refund of a sum of Rs. 27,072 with interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt decreed the suit in part by issuing an injunction restraining the respondent from levying, recovering or companylecting the tax at the enhanced rate and passing a decree against the respondent for refund of a sum of Rs. 27,072 with interest and companyts.

facts.text: The respondent preferred an appeal and the appellant filed cross objections.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal and the appellant filed cross objections.

facts.text: The High Court by its judgment and decree dated February 10, 1953, reversed the judgment of the trial court and dismissed the suit of the appellant with costs throughout. The appellants cross objections were also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court by its judgment and decree dated February 10, 1953, reversed the judgment of the trial companyrt and dismissed the suit of the appellant with companyts throughout. The appellants cross objections were also dismissed.

facts.text: On December 10, 1953, the High Court granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court from the said judgment.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1953, the High Court from granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court from the said judgment.

facts.text: Hence this final appeal questioning the validity of the impugned tax.

anchor.surface_text: Hence this final appeal questioning the validity of the impugned tax.

facts.text: Section 59 of the Bombay District Municipal Act 1901 provided that subject to any general or special orders which the State Government might make... any Municipality after observing the preliminary procedure required by s. 60, and with the sanction of the authority therein mentioned, might impose for the purposes of that Act any of the taxes mentioned in that section.

anchor.surface_text: Section 59 of the Bombay District Municipal Act 1901 provided that subject to any general or special orders which the State Government might make in that behalf any Municipality  a  after observing the preliminary procedure required by s. 60, and  b  with the sanction of the authority therein mentioned, might impose for the purposes of that Act any of the taxes mentioned in that section.

facts.text: The first point urged in this appeal is that the law imposing this tax is covered by entry 50 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, but is really a tax on the appellants trade or calling referred to in entry 46 and that, therefore, the amount of tax cannot under s. 142-A of the Government of India Act, 1935 exceed Rs. 100 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The first point urged in this appeal is that the law imposing this tax is number companyered by entry 50 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, but is really a tax on the appellants trade or calling referred to in entry 46 and that, therefore, the amount of tax cannot under s. 142-A of the Government of India Act, 1935 exceed Rs. 100 per annum.

facts.text: The second point urged before us in support of this appeal is that s. 59 (1) (xi) is unconstitutional in that the legislature had completely abdicated its functions and had delegated essential legislative power to the Municipality to determine the nature of the tax to be imposed on the rate payers.

anchor.surface_text: The second point urged before us in support of this appeal is that s. 59 1  xi  is unconstitutional in that the legislature had companypletely abdicated its functions and had delegated essential legislature power to the Municipality to determine the nature of the tax to be imposed on the rate payers.

facts.text: The last point urged by learned counsel for the appellant is that, under clause (xi) of s. 59 (1), the enhancements of the rates of the tax in 1941 and again in 1948 were illegal in that the municipality had no power to do so under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: The last point urged by learned companynsel for the appellant is that, under clause  xi  of s. 59 1 , the enhancements of the rates of the tax in 1941 and again in 1948 were illegal in that the municipality had numberpower to do so under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.

facts.text: s. 67 of the Bombay District Municipal Act (Bom. III of 1901) which was formerly applicable to municipalities used the word reduce in between the words suspend and abolish.

Section 59 of the Bombay District Municipal Act 1901 provided that subject to any general or special orders which the State Government might make in that behalf any Municipality  a  after observing the preliminary procedure required by s. 60, and  b  with the sanction of the authority therein mentioned, might impose for the purposes of that Act any of the taxes mentioned in that section. After enumerating ten specific heads of taxes, which a municipality companyld levy, a residuary category was set forth in clause  xi  in the words following - Any other tax to the nature and object of which the approval of the Governor in Council shall have been obtained prior to the selection companytemplated in sub-clause  i  of clause  a  of section 60.

concepts.interpretation: Authorises municipalities to impose taxes listed or any other tax with prior approval of Governor in Council after preliminary procedure; residuary clause (xi) not excessive delegation as limited by legislative powers, Act purposes, reasonable relation to duties, and gubernatorial approval.

According to learned companynsel for the appellant the judgment under appeal upholding the validity of such enhancements cannot be supported under s. 60 of that Act. That section runs as follows - Power to 60 1  Subject to the requirements of clause  a  of suspend, reduce the proviso to section 58 a municipality may, except or abolish any as otherwise provided in clause  b  of the proviso existing tax to section 103 at any time for any sufficient reason, suspend, modify or abolish any existing tax by suspending, altering or rescinding any rule prescribing such tax.

issues.text: Whether the law imposing the tax on cinema houses is covered by entry 50 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, or is really a tax on the appellant's trade or calling under entry 46, such that the tax cannot exceed Rs. 100 per annum under s. 142-A?

anchor.surface_text: The first point urged in this appeal is that the law imposing this tax is number companyered by entry 50 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, but is really a tax on the appellants trade or calling referred to in entry 46 and that, therefore, the amount of tax cannot under s. 142-A of the Government of India Act, 1935 exceed Rs. 100 per annum.

issues.text: Whether s. 59(1)(xi) of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925 (and corresponding provision in Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901) is unconstitutional as excessive delegation of essential legislative power to the municipality?

arguments.claim: Power of municipality cannot exceed power of provincial legislature itself.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the power of the municipality cannot exceed the power of the provincial legislature itself and the municipality cannot impose any tax, e.g., income tax which the provincial legislature companyld number itself impose.

arguments.claim: Taxes can only be levied for purposes of the Act, implementing municipal obligations in Ch. VII, reasonable relation to duties like s.54.

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, s. 59 authorises the municipality to impose the taxes therein mentioned for the purposes of this Act. ... What we say is that the tax to be imposed must have some reasonable relation to the duties cast on it by the Act.

arguments.claim: Items i to x indicate kind and nature of taxes authorised, though ejusdem generis strictly inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: In the third place, although the rule of construction based on the principle of ejusdem generis cannot be invoked in this case, for items i to x do number, strictly speaking, belong to the same genus, but they do indicate, to our mind the kind and nature of tax which the municipalities are authorised to impose.

arguments.claim: Taxing power subject to approval of Governor-in-Council, no abdication.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the provincial legislature had certainly number abdicated in favour of the municipality, for the taxing power of the municipality was quite definitely made subject to the approval of the Governor-in-Council.

arguments.claim: Impugned section lays down principle and standard; delegation within permissible limits.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the impugned section did lay down a principle and fix a standard which the municipalities had to follow in imposing a tax and the legislature cannot, in the circumstances, be said to have had abdicated itself and, therefore, the delegation of power to impose any other tax cannot be struck down as being in excess of the permissible limits of delegation of legislative functions.

arguments.claim: Marginal note cannot affect construction of clear body language.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the marginal note cannot affect the construction of the language used in the body of the section if it is otherwise clear and unambiguous see Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai and Co., Bombay 1950 S.C.R. 335 at p. 353.

arguments.claim: s.67 prior Act used 'reduce', changed to 'modify' in s.60 intentionally to widen scope.

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, it should be borne in mind that s. 67 of the Bombay District Municipal Act Bom. III of 1901 which was formerly applicable to municipalities used the word reduce in between the words suspend and abolish and that that section had been reproduced is s. 60 of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, but that in the process of such reproduction the word reduce was dropped and the word modify was introduced.

arguments.claim: s.76 refers to modification involving increase.

anchor.surface_text: Section 76 of this very Act also refers to modification number involving an increase in the amount to be imposed which makes the sense in which the word modify has been used in this Act perfectly clear, namely, that there may be a modification involving an increase.

arguments.claim: 'Modification' implies alteration, applicable to narrow or enlarge.

holdings.text: This point need not detain us long, for it is covered by us in the appellants other appeal No. 145 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This point need not detain us long, for it is covered by us in the appellants other appeal No. 145 of 1955.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The issue is decided in the appellant's other appeal No. 145 of 1955.

holdings.text: We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this contention. [...] the delegation of power to impose any other tax cannot be struck down as being in excess of the permissible limits of delegation of legislative functions.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this contention. In the first place, the power of the municipality cannot exceed the power of the provincial legislature itself and the municipality cannot impose any tax, e.g., income tax which the provincial legislature could not itself impose. In the next place, s. 59 authorises the municipality to impose the taxes therein mentioned for the purposes of this Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Municipal power limited by provincial legislature's power, purposes of Act and relation to duties under s.54 etc., indication from listed taxes, subject to Governor-in-Council approval; section lays down principle and standard.

holdings.text: In our opinion the dropping of the word reduce and the introduction of the word modify in the body of s. 60 of the Act under consideration clearly indicate an intention on the part of legislature to widen the scope of this section and the High Court was right in so construing the same.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Marginal note does not control unambiguous text; deliberate legislative change from prior s.67 'reduce' to 'modify'; consistent with s.76 usage for increase; supported by English precedent on 'modification' including enlargement.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this contention. In the first place, the power of the municipality cannot exceed the power of the provincial legislature itself and the municipality cannot impose any tax, e.g., income tax which the provincial legislature could not itself impose. In the next place, s. 59 authorises the municipality to impose the taxes therein mentioned for the purposes of this Act.

We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this contention. In the first place, the power of the municipality cannot exceed the power of the provincial legislature itself and the municipality cannot impose any tax, e.g., income tax which the provincial legislature could not itself impose. In the next place, s. 59 authorises the municipality to impose the taxes therein mentioned for the purposes of this Act.
